metadata.title: 5 Things To Know: July 14, 2025
metadata.description:
CNBC’s Andrew Ross Sorkin delivers the five things investors need to know ahead of Friday’s trading session. For access to live and exclusive video from CNBC subscribe to CNBC PRO: https://cnb.cx/42d859g

» Subscribe to CNBC TV: https://cnb.cx/SubscribeCNBCtelevision
» Subscribe to CNBC: https://cnb.cx/SubscribeCNBC

transcript.full_text: Five things to know ahead of today's opening bell. Warner Brothers' Superman reboot topping the weekend box office, brought in $122 million in the United States and Canada in its debut weekend. Its global haul estimated two at $217 million. The movie cost $225 million to produce. Of course, there are marketing costs on top of that. Shoppers spending heavily online from last Tuesday to Friday. What some are calling Black Friday in summer. That was led by Amazon's Prime Day. Adobe Analytics saying that online spending grew more than $24 billion across the United States retailers. And uh that was above Adobe's prior forecast. And Reuters reporting that Nvidia's Jensen Huang is going to hold a media briefing in Beijing this week. Uh he's going to be making his second visit to China just in about the past three months. An interview that aired yesterday on CNN, he downplayed the United States' fears that his firm's chips will aid the Chinese military. And speaking of China, the country's export growth beating expectations last month. That was boosted by shipments to non-US markets and a temporary reprieve from US tariffs. And J.P. Morgan's Jamie Dimon has warned about the dangers of private credit, comparing the risks to those of the 2008 financial crisis. But J.P. Morgan now ramping up its efforts in that same area as the growth of private lending has exploded. A new piece in the Wall Street Journal this morning saying that Dimon is now racing to claim a stake before J.P. Morgan is left behind. The report details the bank's strategy to quote, swoop in strategically and profit if there is a meltdown. And I think that's the most important part about this, which is he's not going whole hog into this into this space. The idea is to the extent you can be opportunistic, how do you do it? Uh there's potentially a lot of leverage in this space. I mean, the question always has been in the private credit market. Some people would say it's all matched up perfectly because there's not a duration mismatch, meaning people raise a fund that's starts one year and ends 10 years later and they loan it for 10 years and that's the end of it, so that should be good. The question is whether there's leverage embedded in in those funds. Some of the funds don't have leverage and then there's a lot of funds that have started to get leverage from banks. And the question is how does that all really work itself? And is there a way of measuring or tracking all of that? Not well right now. Not well. Yeah, there we goes. That is one cute dog. What are you looking at? What dog? That is one crypto. They they showed uh uh in the scenes and he was flying and he was he was very cute, so I'm trying to figure out what kind of dog he is. He's a mutt modeled after James Gunn's rescue dog, Ozu. Oh. And the CGI, apparently that dog really isn't flying. Uh the CGI Really? design, uh all of all of his traits are based on James Gunn uh own animal. Usually Superman had a a lab or a German Shepherd. So this is But did you see did you see how cute? Yeah, I did. I think that's going to make the movie. Really uh or at least help. I mean it they they seem to have the right formula. I was thinking reminds me of Underdog. Remember Underdog? He was a pretty studly dog. He was more muttly, right? Yeah, but he was he flew. He was a little superhero. Chestier dog. Save people, save people. coming up, we're going to Talk about that in so long. Underdog.

analysis.summary:
The transcript provides five key updates across different sectors. Warner Brothers' 'Superman' reboot led the recent weekend box office, earning $122 million in North America and $217 million globally, despite costing $225 million to produce. The film's success was partly attributed to the dog character, Crypto, a CGI mutt inspired by director James Gunn's rescue dog, Ozu, which was deemed a 'cute' and potentially impactful element for the movie's appeal.

E-commerce experienced a significant boost from online spending, labeled 'Black Friday in summer,' primarily driven by Amazon's Prime Day. Adobe Analytics reported a growth of over $24 billion in online spending across US retailers, surpassing earlier forecasts and indicating robust consumer activity.

In the technology and geopolitical spheres, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang is scheduled for a media briefing in Beijing this week, marking his second visit to China in three months. Huang recently dismissed US concerns that Nvidia's chips could aid the Chinese military. Meanwhile, China's export growth exceeded expectations last month, buoyed by shipments to non-US markets and a temporary reprieve from US tariffs.

key_points.text: The segment introduces five key things to know ahead of the day's opening bell.
Warner Brothers' Superman reboot topped the recent weekend box office.
The Superman reboot generated $122 million in its debut weekend in the United States and Canada.
Its global earnings for the Superman movie are estimated at $217 million.
The movie cost $225 million to produce, not including marketing costs.
Shoppers engaged in heavy online spending from last Tuesday to Friday, a period some call 'Black Friday in summer'.
This surge in online spending was primarily driven by Amazon's Prime Day.
Adobe Analytics reported that online spending grew by more than $24 billion across United States retailers.
This online spending growth exceeded Adobe's prior forecast.
Reuters is reporting that Nvidia's CEO, Jensen Huang, will hold a media briefing in Beijing this week.
This marks Jensen Huang's second visit to China in approximately the past three months.
In a CNN interview yesterday, Huang downplayed United States' fears that Nvidia's chips would assist the Chinese military.
China's export growth surpassed expectations last month.
The export growth was boosted by increased shipments to non-US markets.
China's export growth also benefited from a temporary reprieve from US tariffs.
Jamie Dimon of J.P. Morgan issued a warning about the dangers of private credit.
Dimon compared the risks within private credit to those that led to the 2008 financial crisis.
Despite Dimon's warnings, J.P. Morgan is increasing its efforts in the private credit sector.
The growth of private lending has seen an explosion.
A new Wall Street Journal report indicates Dimon is racing to secure a stake in the private credit market before J.P. Morgan is left behind.
J.P. Morgan's strategy in private credit is to 'swoop in strategically and profit if there is a meltdown'.
Dimon's approach is opportunistic rather than a full commitment to the private credit space.
The private credit market potentially involves significant leverage.
A key question in the private credit market is the extent of embedded leverage in funds.
Some private credit funds operate without leverage, while others have started acquiring leverage from banks.
Currently, the measurement and tracking of leverage in private credit is not well-developed.
Discussion shifts to a 'cute dog' character from the Superman movie.
The dog character is Crypto, a mutt modeled after director James Gunn's rescue dog, Ozu.
The flying dog in the movie is created using CGI, with its traits based on James Gunn's own animal.
Traditionally, Superman was associated with a lab or German Shepherd dog.
The cuteness of the dog character is expected to contribute positively to the movie's success.
The dog character evokes memories of 'Underdog', a superhero dog.

dates.context: Five things to know ahead of today's opening bell
Superman reboot topping the weekend box office
Shoppers spending heavily online from last Tuesday to Friday
Jensen Huang is going to hold a media briefing in Beijing this week
second visit to China just in about the past three months
An interview that aired yesterday on CNN
the country's export growth beating expectations last month
comparing the risks to those of the 2008 financial crisis
A new piece in the Wall Street Journal this morning

timeline_events.event_description: Warner Brothers' Superman reboot topped the weekend box office, earning $122 million in its US and Canada debut.

Shoppers spent heavily online from last Tuesday to Friday in what was termed 'Black Friday in summer,' driven by Amazon's Prime Day. Adobe Analytics reported online spending grew over $24 billion for US retailers.
Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang is scheduled to hold a media briefing in Beijing.
An interview with Jensen Huang aired on CNN where he downplayed fears about Nvidia's chips aiding the Chinese military.
China's export growth exceeded expectations last month, boosted by shipments to non-US markets and temporary tariff reprieve.
The Wall Street Journal published a new piece this morning detailing J.P. Morgan's strategy to engage with private credit markets.

temporal_patterns.description: Jensen Huang's repeated visits to China, marking his second visit within the past three months.
temporal_patterns.significance: Indicates increased engagement or strategic focus on China by Nvidia's CEO amidst geopolitical tensions.

temporal_patterns.description: The emergence of a 'Black Friday in summer' sales event, led by Amazon's Prime Day, showing a trend of replicating traditional shopping holidays during new periods.
temporal_patterns.significance: Suggests a new seasonal peak for online retail spending, potentially becoming a regular annual event.
temporal_patterns.timespan: Last Tuesday to Friday (specific instance), with implications for future 'summer' events

temporal_patterns.description: The rapid expansion and 'explosion' of the private lending market, leading to major banks like J.P. Morgan strategically increasing their involvement.
temporal_patterns.significance: Highlights a significant shift in financial markets towards private credit, prompting traditional banks to adapt or risk being left behind, despite initial warnings about risks.

temporal_patterns.description: Jamie Dimon's initial warnings about private credit risks (comparing to 2008 financial crisis) followed by J.P. Morgan's strategic move to engage in the same market, intending to 'swoop in strategically and profit if there is a meltdown.'
temporal_patterns.significance: Illustrates a complex corporate strategy where a perceived risk or bubble in the market leads to proactive positioning to capitalize on potential future instability, rather than avoiding the market entirely.

Shoppers spending heavily online from last Tuesday to Friday
Jensen Huang is going to hold a media briefing in Beijing this week
second visit to China just in about the past three months
An interview that aired yesterday on CNN
the country's export growth beating expectations last month
comparing the risks to those of the 2008 financial crisis
A new piece in the Wall Street Journal this morning
